title: Exclusive: PFA urges Premier League to help create fund to support care costs of former footballers living with dementia
text:
The Premier League will be urged to support the creation of a new industry-wide fund to cover the care costs of former professional footballers living with dementia in the build-up to a shareholders’ meeting next month.

The idea, which has been suggested by the Professional Footballers’ Association, follows confirmation last week of the link between playing football and serious neurological disease and an admittance by the players’ union that it cannot alone meet the demand among its 50,000 members for care home costs.

The PFA is now calling for “stakeholders in football to create an industry-wide fund to support former players affected by dementia” and will seek backing from the Premier League and English Football League, as well as the Football Association, Uefa and Fifa.

Families of former players suffering with dementia have felt deeply let down by the limitations of the PFA’s assistance through an annual benevolent fund for former players which is dwarfed by the salary and bonus of its chief executive Gordon Taylor.

That discrepancy will surely weaken the PFA’s argument for financial help from other governing bodies, even if it would realistically still be needed should Taylor or his future successor ultimately accept a much lower salary. Taylor earned more than £2 million last year and the PFA spent only £563,261 on its entire benevolent fund for former players in need. The PFA also spent £9 million on Premier League and Football League youth development and community funds in that same period.
